Lausanne - Printed in The Netherlands WHY DO HOMOGENEOUS ANALOGS OF PHILLIPS (Cr03/Si02) AND UNION CARBIDE (CHROMOCENE/Si02) POLY ETHYLEIVE CATALYSTS FAIL? SOME ANSWERS FROM IR INVESTIGATIONS B- REBENSTORF* and R- LARSSON Division of fnorgareic Chemistry 1, Chemical Center, University of Lard, Box 740, S-220 07 Lund 7 (Sweden) Summary Both title catalysts show strong i.r. bands after adsorption of CO, which are assigned to bridging CO molecules. These CO i.r. bands are at 2120, 2100 and 2035 cm-1 at low temperatures (-145 C) for the CO -reduced Phillips catalyst (Zecchina et a1., 1975) or at 1920, 1825 and 1620 cm: 1- (Union Carbide catalyst). Single-bonded CO is observed showing i_r. bands at 2190, 2186 and 2179 cm: I - shifted to higher wavenumbers than CO gas (2143 cm-1), in contrast to bridging CO - or at 204-6 and 1974 cm -L (and 2008 cm-1), respectively. The single-bonded CO is replaced at low temperatures (Phillips catalyst) or after some days at room tempera ture (Union Carbide catalyst) by bridging CO molecules. These findings support aot only the presence of dinuclear chromium surface complexes, but also further indicate that such surface complexes represent the majority of the chromium. The CO ix. studies make it possible to propose detailed models of the dinuclear chromium surface complexes. The initiation reaction for the polymerization of ethylene could be the addition of one ethylene molecule to one dinuclear surface complex by forming a >M-CH2 CH2_ NIE bridge. Homogeneous analogs for the title catalysts should therefore consist of coordinatively unsaturated dinuclepar complexes, which was not the case in previous studies. Lgt?-oductios Several attempts to convert the heterogeneous Phillips [I - 41 and Union Carbide [5 1 polyethylene catalysts into similarly active homogeneous systems have failed [6 - 9] . To explain this failure, coordination cf reaction *To whom correspondence should be addressed. 248 products [6] or coordinative di.-nerization [8] has been proposed. However, similar poisoning effects should also be possible in the heterogeneous systems. In 1968 it was shown by two different research groups [2, 4] that tile P:iillips catalyst could be reduced to chromium(II) (from chromium(VI)) nearly quantitatively by CO (1 atm, 300 C) [2] and CZI-Lr (1 atm, 135 C) [4] _ The reduced Phillips catalyst was able to polymerize ethylene at room temperature without the induction phase of low activity usually observed f-r the industrial catalyst. It was proposed that during the induction phase the Phillips catalyst is reduced to chromium(II) by ethylene. Therefore, it was concluded that the coordinatively unsaturated chromium(II) surface compound should be the catalytic centre of the Phillips catalyst [2] (or at least its direct precursor). Investigations of this surface compound led to two different structures: mononuclear [10] and dinuelear [11, 12] surface complexes. By re-interpretation of the result that led to the mononuclear structure, however, it could be shown that only dinuclear chromium(II) surface complexes are present in the CO-reduced Phillips catalyst [13] . Recently, it has been shown beyond doubt that a coordinatively unsaturat"3 surface compound of chromium(III) can also polymerize ethylene at room temperature [14, 1 5] - The aim of the present investigations is to apply i.r. studies of adsorbed CO to the chromocene/SiOZ system and to study the CO poisoning of the three polymerization centres. A mechanism for the polymerization of ethylene An often overlooked problem of polymerization mechanisms far the Phillips and Union Carbide catalysts is the missing hydrogen in the initiation reaction. A solution to this problem is the assumption of metallacycles as starting compounds. One of us has previously [18] proposed such a metallapentacycle for the Phillips catalyst, based on the assumption that mononuclear catalytic centres existed. On the basis of dinuclear catalytic centres, the initiation reaction can be even simpler by assuming the insertion of one ethylene molecule between the two metal atoms of a dinuclear complex (S.3heme 3). In such a reaction model, no C-H bond has to be broken, which is, however, the case if the polymer leaves the catalytic centre. Polymerization may proceed by the Cossee mechanism and the catalytic centre O be poisoned by CO, as shown in structure (e) in Scheme 3. Returning to the attempts to convert the two polyethylene catalysts into homogeneous systems, we suggest in the case of bis(triphenylsilyl)chromate [6] , that the much higher pressure necessary for polymerization (at least one order of magnitude) may be explained by assuming a metallapentacycle mechanism [18] . In the case of chromorganyls [7] the oxygen bridge between the two. chromium ions will most likely also be split during dissolution and so destroy the catalytic centre. For cyclopentadienylchromium oxides [8] and chromiurn(II) alcoholates [9] , coordinative, dior polymerization most likely prevents catalytic activity. Breaking the coordinative bonds, for instance, on reaction with ethylene, will produce mononuclear complexes. Therefore the faaure in the attempts to convert the two cattalysts into homogeneous systems may be generalised as a failure in synthesizing coordinatively unsaturated dinuclear chromium(II) (or chromium(III)) complexes. coredata.dc:description: Both title catalysts show strong i.r. bands after adsorption of CO, which are assigned to bridging CO molecules. These CO i.r. bands are at 2120, 2100 and 2035 cm−1 at low temperatures (−145 °C) for the CO-reduced Phillips catalyst (Zecchina , 1975) or at 1920, 1825 and 1620 cm−1 (Union Carbide catalyst).Single-bonded CO is observed showing i.r. bands at 2190, 2186 and 2179 cm−1—shifted to higher wavenumbers than CO gas (2143 cm−1), in contrast to bridging CO — or at 2046 and 1974 cm− (and 2008 cm−1), respectively. The single-bonded CO is replaced at low temperatures (Phillips catalyst) or after some days at room temperature (Union Carbide catalyst) by bridging CO molecules. These findings support not only the presence of dinuclear chromium surface complexes, but also further indicate that such surface complexes represent the majority ofthe chromium. The CO i.r. studies make it possible to propose detailed models of the dinuclear chromium surface complexes. The initiation reaction for the polymerization of ethylene could be the addition of one ethylene molecule to one dinuclear surface complex by forming a bridge. Homogeneous analogs for the title catalysts should therefore consist of coordinatively unsaturated dinuclear complexes, which was not the case in previous studies.
